sources.title: The Hitch-Hiker - Weirdness Bad Movie
sources.description: Public Access TV show "Weirdness Really Bad Movie" hosts public domain movies and ads clean comedy sketches enjoyable for the whole family. Today's film is Ida Lupino's 1953 "The Hitch-Hiker"

sources.title: The Hitch-Hiker, 1953 film noir directed by Ida Lupino “first film noir directed by a woman”
sources.channelName: Public Domain Movies - Classic Old Movies

sources.title: The Hitch-Hiker (restored, with intro and outro) (1953, film noir, imdb score: 6.9)
sources.description: The Hitch-Hiker is a 1953 American independent film noir thriller directed by Ida Lupino , who co-wrote it with her former husband Collier Young , and starring Edmond O'Brien , William Talman and Frank Lovejoy . Based on the 1950 killing spree of Billy Cook , the film follows two friends who are taken hostage by a serial-murdering hitchhiker during an automobile trip to Mexico . The Hitch-Hiker was the first mainstream-released American film of its type directed by a woman. It was selected in 1998 for preservation in the United States National Film Registry as being "culturally, historically or aesthetically significant."

sources.title: The Hitch-Hiker (Film-Noir 1953) Directed by Ida Lupino (b&w + Colorized)
sources.description:
Duo Movie with :
00:00 Black & White version of The Hitch-Hiker
1:10:45 Colorized version 

The Hitch-Hiker is a 1953 American independent film noir thriller co-written and directed by Ida Lupino. The film was regarded as the first American mainstream film directed by a woman 

Inspired by a real-life 1950 crime spree of of Billy Cook, The Hitch-Hiker follows two friends who are taken hostage by a dangerous hitchhiker during a road trip to Mexico.

Main Actors:
Edmond O'Brien as Roy Collins
Frank Lovejoy as Gilbert Bowen
William Talman as Emmett Myers
José Torvay as Captain Alvarado
Wendell Niles as Himself (Radio Announcer)
Jean Del Val as Inspector General
Clark Howat as Government Agent
Natividad Vacío as Jose
Rodney Bell as William Johnson
